toc_entry.title: The Wild Side Of Town
toc_entry.description: You don’t have to go to the country or the zoo to see wild animals; there are lizards in downtown buildings, gators in the creeks, and deer in the parking lots.

toc_entry.title: The Man In the Black Hat
toc_entry.description: Clinton Manges built his empire on brushland and oil wells, political contributions and lawsuits. His influence extends to the state capitol and oil company boardrooms. To get where he is, he studied under three masters of South Texas.

toc_entry.title: On the Links
toc_entry.description: Golf, glorious golf. A hook here, a slice there. So what if you can’t break a hundred. A cartful of cool, casual summer clothes will keep you looking like a million.

toc_entry.title: The Resistol Hat
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: Whether it’s made of straw or ermine, this is the cowboy hat.

toc_entry.title: Last Respects
toc_entry.description: The death of Uncle Henry saddened my whole far-flung family, but the gathering at his funeral was an occasion for telling stories and recalling the joys of a smalltown upbringing.

toc_entry.title: Give Me a Job
toc_entry.description: In my village in Oaxaca I had heard about those who made it big in El Norte, and I wanted to become one of them. But I didn’t know how hard life in Houston would be without papers, money, or a job.

toc_entry.title: Buffalo Gal
toc_entry.subtitle: Western Art
toc_entry.description: An interpretation of a classic genre.

toc_entry.title: Someday You’ll Thank Me For This
toc_entry.subtitle: Kids
toc_entry.description: You can lead a child to culture, but can you make him like it?

toc_entry.title: Move Over, Southfork
toc_entry.subtitle: Lifestyles
toc_entry.description: Up for sale in Dallas, the Shanbaum house boasts a whopping 28,000 square fee, and what may be Texas’ most comprehensive collection of sixties and seventies kitsch—along with a $2.75 million price tag.

toc_entry.title: J Is For Jobs
toc_entry.subtitle: Education
toc_entry.description: Houston’s career-oriented magnet schools are putting too much emphasis on work and too little on education.

toc_entry.title: Top o’ the Pops
toc_entry.subtitle: Popular Music
toc_entry.description: The fare offered by the Houston Pops Orchestra may not be highbrow, but conductor Ned Battista thinks it’s american music at its best.

toc_entry.title: The Intellectuals’ Dear Abby
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: A new study of sociologist C. Wright Mills is adequate but uninspired; this year’s Texas Institute of Letters fiction prize has gone to a fine first novel.

toc_entry.title: The Roar Of the Crowd
toc_entry.description: Getting with the programs, getting to know the Yellow Rose, getting it right in Pharr.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A selective statewide guide to amusements and events.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: Coming to grips with al Lipscomb, Dallas critic turned city councilman; remembering the clip joints along Fort Worth’s infamous outlaw alley; flipping for San angelo, a honey of a West Texas town; taking a bizarre trip through Texas on Gary Hart’s press plane.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: The leaning Tower of peace, aaagh . . .; at last we learn what the “public” in Republican stands for; how do you spell relief? D-I-S-A-S-T-E-R; parks lose out yet again.
